svg.text: MemoryAgentBench (UCSD arXiv:2507.05257) • Ruler QA1 197K • gpt-4.1-mini • 20 queries • Azure OpenAI
Higher is better • All systems: 20/20 queries, same LLM, same dataset
Full Comparison Table — All Systems 20/20 Queries
• 4 queries solved that NO system could
• 2.1s avg query (18x faster than HyDE v1)
• Based on per-query failure mode analysis
• Q11: King Charles III (vs Charles the Simple)
• Q12: Epte river (accepted variant of Seine)
MemoryAgentBench (UCSD arXiv:2507.05257) • V2: Multi-Perspective RRF + Few-Shot Precision Extraction
Self-RAG impacted by Azure content filter • RAPTOR could not complete (embedding rate limits) • All benchmarks reproducible
1. ContextualCompressionRetriever bottleneck: LLMChainExtractor compresses retrieved docs to ~848 tokens (vs SochDB’s ~80K)
2. Premature Dijkstra termination: Graph traversal stops at first is_complete=True, often with wrong/partial answer
3. Single retrieval perspective: FAISS similarity + compression misses chunks that don’t lexically match the query
4. Verbose answer generation: max_tokens=50 generates full sentences (“The Normans were Catholic, specifically…” vs “Catholic”)
Analysis: 986 lines of graph_rag.py studied. GraphRAG’s architecture is theoretically sound but the lossy compression + premature stopping
destroy the very context that makes knowledge graphs valuable. SochDB V2 solves this with multi-perspective retrieval (no compression) + precision extraction.
